ThingDef.label: chicken
ThingDef.description: The most traditional farm bird, the chicken is raised for its eggs and meat. It grows very quickly and lays eggs very often.

ThingDef.label: pig
ThingDef.description: The pig was one of the first animals domesticated by humans. It is commonly raised for meat, and is easy to feed because of its omnivorous diet. Though pigs are self-serving by disposition, they can be trained in complex tasks.

ThingDef.label: cow
ThingDef.description: A large domesticated ungulate, cows have been bred for millennia to produce huge amounts of milk, meat, and leather. They are exceptionally gentle creatures and will never seek revenge, no matter how many times they are harmed. Most of them are so adapted to farm life that they cannot survive in the wild.

ThingDef.label: alpaca
ThingDef.description: A medium-sized ungulate closely related to the llama, the alpaca is often farmed for its remarkably soft wool.

ThingDef.label: duck
ThingDef.description: A very common type of farm bird, also appearing in the wild, the duck is raised for its delicious meat. It grows quick but lays eggs quite rarely.

ThingDef.label: bison
ThingDef.description: A large plant eating mammal appearing in the savannah wilderness. Tamed are quite docile, but enraged are fast and dangerous.

ThingDef.label: goat
ThingDef.description: Naturally curious about the world, goats are among the friendliest domesticated creature bred by mankind.

ThingDef.label: goose
ThingDef.description: A domesticated bird kept by humans as poultry for it's eggs and meat. Lays eggs very often, however they take a long time to hatch.

ThingDef.label: yak
ThingDef.description: Yaks are robust cattle with a bulky frame, short but thick legs, and rounded cloven hooves that are splayed to help them walk in snow.

ThingDef.label: guinea pig
ThingDef.description: Neither a pig or a creature from Guinea, these little rodents are bred to be a household pet and a delicious dinner.

ThingDef.label: donkey
ThingDef.description: A small relative of the horse, domesticated in ancient times for farm work. Its goofy call is simultaneously annoying and endearing.
